content.text: A text view displays multiline, styled text content, which can optionally be editable.

content.description: A stylized illustration of a text view component showing multiline text content within a bordered container. The illustration demonstrates the concept of text views with dimension indicators showing the flexible height capability.
content.composition: Central text container with coral/salmon colored background, containing multiple lines of serif text. Gray dashed lines with small squares at corners indicate resizable/flexible dimensions. The container is horizontally centered.
content.technicalDetails: Shows a text view UI component mockup with visual indicators for flexible sizing
textInImage: The interface is not merely a visual display—in fact, it's possible to have an interface with no visual display at all. A human interface is the sum of all communication between the computer and user. It's what presents information to the user and accepts information from the user. It's what actually puts the computer's power into the user's hands.
content.contextualRelevance: Hero illustration demonstrating what a text view looks like and its capability to display multiline styled text content

content.text: Text views can be any height and allow scrolling when the content extends outside of the view. By default, content within a text view is aligned to the leading edge and uses the system label color. In iOS, iPadOS, and visionOS, if a text view is editable, a keyboard appears when people select the view.

Use a text view when you need to display text that's long, editable, or in a special format. Text views differ from text fields and labels in that they provide the most options for displaying specialized text and receiving text input. If you need to display a small amount of text, it's simpler to use a label or — if the text is editable — a text field.
content.boldText: Use a text view when you need to display text that's long, editable, or in a special format.

content.text: Keep text legible. Although you can use multiple fonts, colors, and alignments in creative ways, it's essential to maintain the readability of your content. It's a good idea to adopt Dynamic Type so your text still looks good if people change text size on their device. Be sure to test your content with accessibility options turned on, such as bold text. For guidance, see Accessibility and Typography.
Make useful text selectable. If a text view contains useful information such as an error message, a serial number, or an IP address, consider letting people select and copy it for pasting elsewhere.
No additional considerations for macOS, visionOS, or watchOS.

Show the appropriate keyboard type. Several different keyboard types are available, each designed to facilitate a different type of input. To streamline data entry, the keyboard you display when editing a text view needs to be appropriate for the type of content. For guidance, see Virtual keyboards.
You can display text in tvOS using a text view. Because text input in tvOS is minimal by design, tvOS uses text fields for editable text instead.

pages.pageSummary: Apple Human Interface Guidelines documentation page for Text views component. The page describes text views as multiline, styled text content displays with optional editability. It provides best practices for usage including when to use text views vs labels/text fields, maintaining legibility with Dynamic Type, and enabling text selection for useful content. Platform-specific guidance is provided for iOS/iPadOS (keyboard types) and tvOS (display-only usage). Resources link to related HIG components (Labels, Text fields, Combo boxes) and developer documentation (SwiftUI Text, UIKit UITextView, AppKit NSTextView).

sections.title: Text views
sections.summary: Introduction defining text views as multiline, styled text content displays that can optionally be editable, with scrolling capability and leading edge alignment by default.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Three key best practices: 1) Use text views for long, editable, or specially formatted text (vs labels/text fields for simple content), 2) Keep text legible with Dynamic Type and accessibility testing, 3) Make useful text selectable for copying.

sections.title: Platform considerations

subsections.title: iOS, iPadOS
subsections.summary: Show appropriate keyboard type for the content being entered

subsections.title: tvOS
subsections.summary: Text views display text but tvOS uses text fields for editable text due to minimal text input design

sections.summary: Platform-specific considerations with no additional notes for macOS, visionOS, or watchOS. iOS/iPadOS should show appropriate keyboard types. tvOS uses text views for display only, with text fields for editable content.

keyTerms.definition: A UI component that displays multiline, styled text content, which can optionally be editable
Apple's accessibility feature that allows users to change text size system-wide, which apps should support
The starting edge for text alignment (left in LTR languages, right in RTL languages)
The default color used for text content in text views, which adapts to light/dark mode
A simpler UI component for single-line, editable text (contrast with text views for multiline)
A UI component for displaying non-editable, typically short text

keyFindings: Text views can be any height and allow scrolling when content extends outside the view
Default content alignment is leading edge with system label color
In iOS, iPadOS, and visionOS, editable text views trigger keyboard appearance on selection
Text views provide more options than text fields or labels for specialized text display and input
Use labels or text fields for small amounts of text; text views for long, editable, or specially formatted text
Dynamic Type adoption is recommended for accessibility
Useful text (error messages, serial numbers, IP addresses) should be selectable for copying
iOS/iPadOS should display appropriate keyboard types for the content being edited
tvOS uses text views only for display; text fields handle editable text due to minimal input design
No additional considerations exist for macOS, visionOS, or watchOS

defaultBehavior.scrolling: enabled when content exceeds view bounds

designDecisions.decision: Use text view vs text field vs label
designDecisions.rationale: Text views for long, editable, or specially formatted text; text fields for short editable text; labels for short non-editable text
Ensures text remains legible when users change system text size

designDecisions.decision: Enable text selection for useful content
designDecisions.rationale: Allows users to copy error messages, serial numbers, IP addresses for pasting elsewhere
Streamlines data entry by showing keyboard optimized for content type
